rounds.response:
I'm analyzing the value impact of the proposal:

Current Portfolio Value:  
5×6 (30)  + 13×9 (117)  + 16×14 (224)  + 16×22 (352)  + 13×33 (429) = 1 152

If I accept:  
+5 Wheat → 30  +5 Wood → 45  −3 Brick → −66  −2 Sheep → −28  
Net change: −19 value-points

So this trade would lower my total worth.  
Rejecting now keeps my position intact and leaves value on the bargaining table in case we can create a mutually beneficial alternative later.

[Deny]

rounds.response:
Let me first calculate my total value before anything happens:

- Wheat 5 × 6  = 30
- Wood 13 × 9  = 117
- Sheep 16 × 14 = 224
- Brick 16 × 22 = 352
- Ore 13 × 33 = 429
Total value = 30 + 117 + 224 + 352 + 429 = 1 152

My goal is every exchange must raise this total by as much as possible, ideally at least a 2-value-per-unit ratio.

The previous offer from Player 0 was:
- Gives me (5 Wheat @ 6 each + 5 Wood @ 9 each) = 30 + 45 = 75 value
- Takes from me (3 Brick @ 22 each + 2 Sheep @ 14 each) = 66 + 28 = 94 value  
Net change: –19 (worse), so rejecting was correct.

Now it’s Turn 3 (after two completed back-and-forths). I need to propose a trade that Player 0 is actually likely to accept but still improves my own score.

I notice both sides are currently short on Ore relative to other goods (I value Ore at 33). To make Ore attractive to Player 0 I’m willing to give a bit of a premium.

I propose:

[Offer: 3 Ore -> 4 Brick, 1 Wood]

rounds.response:
I see the historical log.  
At this moment:

- Turn 6 has just finished (both players passed).  
- It is the very start of turn 7.  
- No offer is on the table yet.

To maximise the sum of resource values I want to:

1. Push high-margin extras.  
   – Ore (value 33) is my scarcest high-value item; I do not intend to sell more than one.  
   – Brick (value 22) remains my favourite, followed by Wheat (value 6) which I currently hold very little of.  
   – Wood (value 9) is my least-liked surplus; Sheep at value 14 is okay but I can still spare some.

2. Make an offer whose perceived value is attractive to Player 0, but whose true value to me is lower than what I receive.

Therefore, I bundle:

- 5 Wood – low value per piece in my set, exceeds my needs.  
- 3 Sheep – decent, but I have 16 and can still spare after giving 3 away.

I request:

- 4 Brick – very high utility for me (short in absolute terms and currently highest marginal value).  
- 2 Wheat – I had only 5; getting 2 more keeps me flexible.

Net impact on my resources (before acceptance):

- Lose 15 points (5 Wood ×3 + 3 Sheep ×4 → 3×9 = 27 and 3×14 = 42, total value 69)  
- Gain 100 points (4 Brick ×22 = 88 and 2 Wheat ×6 = 12, total 100)  

Even if Player 0 balks, the framing is generous (2 resource types packaged against 2 demanded), which invites counter-proposals instead of outright rejection.

[Offer: 5 Wood, 3 Sheep -> 4 Brick, 2 Wheat]

rounds.response:
Let me quickly recap what has actually happened so far (I discarded the mis-ordered descriptions so I only look at the actions):

1  P0 → P1 [Offer: 5 Wheat, 5 Wood → 3 Brick, 2 Sheep]  
  P1 → P0 [Deny]

2  P1 → P0 [Offer: 3 Ore → 4 Brick, 1 Wood]  
  P0 → P1 [Deny]

3  P1 → P0 [Offer: 5 Sheep, 5 Ore → 10 Brick, 5 Wood]  
  P0 → P1 [Deny]

4  P1 → P0 [Offer: 5 Wood, 3 Sheep → 4 Brick, 2 Wheat]  
  P0 → P1 [Deny]

Turn-counter so far: 4 trades initiated, 1 per full turn → 4 turns burned  
Turns left: 10-4 = 6 for further bargaining.

I checked every one of my own offers; they all raise my net value, yet every one was rejected.  
There is clearly room for Player 0 (they seem to own no ore at all, plenty of brick and wheat).  
Let me make a more appealing package now.

[Offer: 4 Ore, 1 Wheat -> 5 Brick, 2 Wood]

rounds.response:
Let’s work out what each of the proposed trades did to my current reserve:

Current inventory values
• Wheat 5×6  = 30
• Wood 13×9 = 117
• Sheep 16×14 = 224
• Brick 16×22 = 352
• Ore   13×33 = 429
Total value = 1 152

Value per single resource
Wheat 6, Wood 9, Sheep 14, Brick 22, Ore 33.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Player 0’s 1st offer
“Give me 3 Brick (66) & 2 Sheep (28)  →  I get 5 Wheat (30) & 5 Wood (45).”

Net outcome for me:
+30 +45  (in)  –66 –28 (out)  = –19
Decline: ✔ [Deny]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
My 1st offer (Turn 3)
“Give 3 Ore (99)  →  get 4 Brick (88) & 1 Wood (9).”

Net outcome: –99 +88 +9 = –2
Decline: ✔ [Deny]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
My 2nd offer (Turn 5)
“Give 5 Sheep (70) & 5 Ore (165)  →  get 10 Brick (220) & 5 Wood (45).”

Net outcome: –70 –165 +220 +45 = +30
That would be profitable for me, but you still rejected it.  
No new offer coming in, so I simply:
[Deny]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
My 3rd offer (Turn 7)
“Give 5 Wood (45) & 3 Sheep (42)  →  get 4 Brick (88) & 2 Wheat (12).”

Net outcome: –45 –42 +88 +12 = +13
Declined again.  My cue:
[Deny]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
What next?
We’re approaching the mid-game (Turns 9-10) and every strictly positive-value offer I’ve made so far has been swatted away.  
If I want my value to tick up, I need to put on the table something Player 0 actually wants while keeping my own gain positive—but shortcuts of high-value Ore/Sheep clearly weren’t tempting enough.

Let me try a narrower trade with good relative value for Player 0:

[Offer: 1 Ore -> 3 Wheat]

Value check: I give 1 Ore (33), receive 3 Wheat (18).  
My net: –15.  (Bad for me, good for them—so they might accept, yet it still moves overall trades toward equilibrium.)

Actually, let’s flip the ratio to stay on the profit side of the line.

Better revised offer:

[Offer: 1 Ore -> 2 Brick]

I give 1 Ore (33), get 2 Brick (44);   net +11 to me.  
Both sides see tangible gain: Player 0 receives a high-value Ore and only gives up cheaper Brick; I add solid value.
